dataset.title: Organic layer thickness: Wickersham fire sites (1971 - 2004)

address.deliveryPoint: USDA-Agricultural Research Service PO Box 757200 University of Alaska Fairbanks

abstract.para: In June of 1971, the Wickersham fire burned 6313 ha in an open black spruce forest underlain with permafrost and provided an opportunity to study fire and fireline effects on the rate and patterns of permafrost, soil, and vegetation recovery. When wildfire burns through a northern black spruce forest the degree of soil organic layer consumption greatly influences the post-fire community characteristics. The construction of firelines with heavy machinery involves the complete removal of vegetation and the soil organic layer down to mineral soil and likewise affects the community characteristics after fire and fire suppression. Reduction in organic layer thickness and the subsequent loss of thermal insulation has been shown to cause increased soil temperatures and increased depth of thaw of the active layer. This long-term study is a comparison between the organic layer thickness on firelines, burned and unburned open black spruce forests underlain by ice rich permafrost.

section.title: corrections
section.para:
For consistency, we have altered several organic layer names: ?Loose Organic Layer? on the 1980 original data sheets (described as old organic layer from fire, usually dry and plant parts visible) is now ?Partially Decomposed?. ?Peat? and ?Fibrous? on the original data sheets (layers above the well decomposed Humus layer) are now classed as ?Intermediately Decomposed?.
In 1971, the east side unburned control (2130), and the east and west side firelines (2012 & 2010) were not measured. In 1980, all west side sites (2001, 2002, 2003, 2010) were not measured. In 2004, the east side unburned control (2130) and all west side sites (2001, 2002, 2003, 2010) were not measured.
In 1971, The depth of the total organic layer was measured at the 20 vegetation plots. Individual organic horizons were not differentiated. In 1980, 1995, and 2004, individual organic horizons were differentiated and measured at the 10 thaw probing points in each site. The depth of the total organic layer was calculated from summing the individual organic horizon depths.

section.title: Experimental Design
section.para:
Organic layer depths were measured at 1-2 months, 9 years, 24 years, and 33 years after the fire in firelines, burned, and unburned control sites on the east and west sides of Cushman Creek. Study sites are the same as the ?Active layer depths: Wickersham fire sites? data set, as follows.
On the east side of Cushman Creek, three study sites were established: an unburned black spruce stand (2130), a heavily burned black spruce stand (2004), and a fireline (2012) between the unburned and burned stands where vegetation and organic material were removed by bulldozer down to mineral soil. At each site on the east side, ten permanent probe points (marked with fiberglass poles) at 2 m intervals were established on a transect perpendicular to the fireline. On the west side of Cushman Creek, four study sites were established: an unburned black spruce stand (2003), a lightly burned black spruce stand (2001), a heavily burned black spruce stand (2002), and a fireline (2010) between the heavily and lightly burned stands. The west side fireline transect was established similar to the east side sites (10 probe points at 2 m intervals, perpendicular to the fireline). In the west side unburned control, heavy burn, and light burn sites, stakes from 20 permanent vegetation plots were used as sampling points (10 to 20 plots were sampled). The vegetation plots were spaced at 30 m intervals, usually in 4 rows of 5 plots.
Burn severity was evaluated as lightly burned (2001) if less than 50 percent of the ground surface was blackened, the lesser vegetation was not consumed, branchlets were still present on trees, and tree crowns were scorched but not consumed. Burn severity was evaluated as heavily burned (2002 & 2004) if more than 90 percent of the ground surface was blackened, and the lesser vegetation and tree crowns were consumed (Viereck and Dyrness, 1979). Using more recent standards of burn severity, the heavily burned stands (2002 & 2004) would be classified as ?moderately burned?, with a partially consumed organic layer, shallow ash layer present, but with woody twig parts remaining (Viereck et al. 1979).
Due to the long-term nature of this study, methods and sampling locations were modified over the years. See corrections/comments headings for methods details. See site maps for a detailed history of sampling locations in each site and the most recent plot/pole labels and locations for future sampling.

section.title: Methods
section.para: Near each probe pole or vegetation plot, organic horizon thickness was measured either 1) on the side of the hole remaining from a removed soil core, or 2) on the face of a soil wedge removed from the soil with a shovel. Soil organic horizons were separated into four different classes based on the degree of decomposition of organic matter: moss/litter, partially decomposed, intermediately decomposed, and humus. The total organic layer thickness was calculated by summing the four organic horizons together. All measurements are in centimeter units.
